body: I am not sure if this helps.. Have you seen the the `static_files` example ?
Indeed, this is covered in the [static_files example](https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/tree/master/examples/static_files).

I had not seen that, thanks! I did eventually find [the bit about segments parameters](https://rocket.rs/guide/requests/#dynamic-segments) which has that same code as an example, but I still think a helper that simplified this extremely common use case would be nice. It took me a while to find that part of the documentation because I was looking around for "static file serving" and I did not expect to find it under "Dynamic Segments". :)
I think the way to do it right now is sufficiently simple, just showing how  in the guide under "Serving Static Files" or something alike would suffice.
I think it would be best to offer something that supports HTTP caching.
I have a question I am using bootstrap only (/css/bootstrap.min.css, /css/bootstrap-theme.min.css) It shows errors in console (GET /css/bootstrap-theme.min.css.map:) ?? any reason about this =?
@marti1125 Your browser is sending a request for the source map files (*.map) but they don't exist in the directory. Presumably you have developer tools open.

issue.title: Can't request static file twice

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: no bug
labels.description: The reported bug was confirmed nonexistent

issue.body:
Hi,

I've created the following two static file functions: 
```rust
#[get("/")]
fn index() -> io::Result<NamedFile> {
    NamedFile::open("../ui/web/index.html")
}

#[get("/<file>")]
fn files(file: String) -> Option<NamedFile> {
    NamedFile::open(Path::new("../ui/web/").join(file)).ok()
}
```

The first request is working, like expected. The second request (from chrome browser) didn't sent a response for 20-30 seconds.
I run this under mac os x and with `cargo run`

Is it a bug, or did I make a failure?

Thanks,
Robert

issue.title: Serve static files with query parameters
issue.body:
Hi
I implemented the static files route based on the guide and the examples.
```
#[get("/static/<file..>")]
fn static_files(file: PathBuf) -> Option<NamedFile> {
    NamedFile::open(Path::new("static/").join(file)).ok()
}
```
It worked very well until some scss code requested a font with a query parameter:
`http://localhost:8000/static/fonts/thefont.woff?v=0.1`

Rocket returned 404. Initially I thought that `FileBuff` was trying to open the file `thefont.woff?v=0.1`, but to my surprise the error is because the route doesn't match because of the query parameters.

At the end I added another route:
```
#[get("/static/<file..>?<q>")]
fn static_files_q(file: PathBuf, q: &str) -> Option<NamedFile> {
    static_files(file)
}
```
That does the trick, but rustc complains
```
[Running cargo run]
   Compiling pallet_jack v0.1.0 (file:///home/nnieto/Code/pu/palletjack)
warning: unused variable: `q`
  --> src/main.rs:22:34
   |
22 | fn static_files_q(file: PathBuf, q: &str) -> Option<NamedFile> {
   |                                  ^
   |
   = note: #[warn(unused_variables)] on by default

    Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 10.6 secs
     Running `target/debug/pallet_jack`
```
**What is the elegant way to serve static files and ignore query ?**

Note: This is similar to issue #239 But I didn't want to hijack the thread.

body: Without actually running it, it looks like the static files example would be vulnerable to a [path traversal attack](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Path_Traversal). Is there anything preventing this?

issue.title: Handling Range header
issue.body:
Since almost every fully featured http server handles the `Range` header by default, I think Rocket should too.

Rocket should add the header `Accept-Ranges: bytes` to every response by default. Maybe have this as a config option? If disabled send `Accept-Ranges: none` and disable `Range` handling.

If a `Range` header is present, Rocket should automatically slice the body to the required range and set the status to `206 Partial Content` or fail with `416 Range Not Satisfiable`.

If additionally an `If-Range` header is present, a validity test of the partial range is needed. Otherwise send the whole file.

For `Range` requests with multiple ranges the `Content-Type` should also be set to `multipart/byteranges`. This requires additional handling of boundaries and part specific headers. (This is also needed to handle `multipart/form-data` requests).

One implementation option would be directly into Rocket itself, without any user facing api (other than perhaps a config option).

Another approach would be to provide a fairing in rocket-contrib. (users would need to opt-in manually)

Hyper does provide a type for the `If-Range` and the `Content-Range` header, not for the `Range` header itself though.

Relevant RFC: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7233

issue.title: Overly strict FromSegments implementation for PathBuf
issue.body:
In the interest of safety, the implementation of `FromSegments` for `PathBuf` ([code](
https://github.com/SergioBenitez/Rocket/blob/8b1aaed0cecb0a26dde8f1aa4ce89a2a4003f957/lib/src/request/param.rs#L339)) rejects all segments that start with a dot (`.`). I believe this is overly strict, since

1. The dot-dot case (a filename of exactly `..`) is already handled.
2. A single dot segment (exactly `.`) could also be valid, and just skipped.
3. Lots of hidden files start with `.`, such as `.gitignore` and other config files.

In my use case I only require the third case, as I am trying to create a file browser, where the path is specified as `<path..>` and `path: PathBuf`. However, such a route cannot browse a file with a name starting with a dot, and I get a `Failed to parse 'path': BadStart('.')` error message. 

I can reproduce this behavior on version `0.3.6` on ArchLinux, but looking at the code I can see it is present in `master` as well.

body:
I just remembered that [tilpner/includedir](https://github.com/tilpner/includedir) is another solution to this, if you don't mind pulling your entire website into your executable.

Edit: it's definitely not a comprehensive solution, but it's an interesting place to start.

@quadrupleslap Including everything is the binary is cool, but this also doesn't handle things like `Not-Modified`. My small project is aimed to provide a pretty solid solution for static file serving with different backends and support for caching, ranges, compression, directory listing. It's not there yet, but since I need these features, it won't be long until it has these properly implemented.
